1.brief: (by implication) very widely used as a relative conjunction or adverb (as below); often largely modified by other particles annexed
not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles
properly, covered, i.e. dark; abstractly, obscurity, i.e. distress
who, which, what, that; also (as an adverb and a conjunction) when, where, how, because, in order that, etc.
narrowness; figuratively, distress
time, especially (adverb with preposition) now, when, etc.
first, in place, time or rank (as adjective or noun)
to be (causatively, make) light, literally (swift, small, sharp, etc.) or figuratively (easy, trifling, vile, etc.)
the earth (at large, or partitively a land)
Zebulon, a son of Jacob; also his territory and tribe
the earth (at large, or partitively a land)
Naphtali, a son of Jacob, with the tribe descended from him, and its territory
hinder; generally, late or last; specifically (as facing the east) western
to be heavy, i.e. in a bad sense (burdensome, severe, dull) or in a good sense (numerous, rich, honorable; causatively, to make weighty (in the same two senses)
a road (as trodden); figuratively, a course of life or mode of action, often adverb

a sea (as breaking in noisy surf) or large body of water; specifically (with the article), the Mediterranean Sea; sometimes a large river, or an artifical basin; locally, the west, or (rarely) the south
properly, a region across; but used only adverbially (with or without a preposition) on the opposite side (especially of the Jordan; ususally meaning the east)
Jarden, the principal river of Palestine
Galil (as a special circuit) in the North of Palestine
a foreign nation; hence, a Gentile; also (figuratively) a troop of animals, or a flight of locusts

2.brief: a people (as a congregated unit); specifically, a tribe (as those of Israel); hence (collectively) troops or attendants; figuratively, a flock
to walk (in a great variety of applications, literally and figuratively)
the dark; hence (literally) darkness; figuratively, misery, destruction, death, ignorance, sorrow, wickedness
to see, literally or figuratively (in numerous applications, direct and implied, transitive, intransitive and causative)
illumination or (concrete) luminary (in every sense, including lightning, happiness, etc.)
great (in any sense); hence, older; also insolent
properly, to sit down (specifically as judge. in ambush, in quiet); by implication, to dwell, to remain; causatively, to settle, to marry
the earth (at large, or partitively a land)
shade of death, i.e. the grave (figuratively, calamity)
illumination or (concrete) luminary (in every sense, including lightning, happiness, etc.)
above, over, upon, or against (yet always in this last relation with a downward aspect) in a great variety of applications

3.brief: a foreign nation; hence, a Gentile; also (figuratively) a troop of animals, or a flight of locusts
not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles
to be (causatively make) large (in various senses, as in body, mind, estate or honor, also in pride)
probably to brighten up, i.e. (figuratively) be (causatively, make) blithe or gleesome
the face (as the part that turns); used in a great variety of applications (literally and figuratively); also (with prepositional prefix) as a preposition (before, etc.)
severed, i.e. harvest (as reaped), the crop, the time, the reaper, or figuratively; also a limb (of a tree, or simply foliage)
who, which, what, that; also (as an adverb and a conjunction) when, where, how, because, in order that, etc.
properly, to spin round (under the influence of any violent emotion), i.e. usually rejoice, or (as cringing) fear
to be smooth (figuratively); by implication (as smooth stones were used for lots) to apportion or separate

4.brief: (by implication) very widely used as a relative conjunction or adverb (as below); often largely modified by other particles annexed
properly, self (but generally used to point out more definitely the object of a verb or preposition, even or namely)
a yoke (as imposed on the neck), literally or figuratively
properly, self (but generally used to point out more definitely the object of a verb or preposition, even or namely)

a branch (as extending); figuratively, a tribe; also a rod, whether for chastising (figuratively, correction), ruling (a sceptre), throwing (a lance), or walking (a staff; figuratively, a support of life, e.g. bread)
the neck (between the shoulders) as the place of burdens; figuratively, the spur of ahill
a scion, i.e. (literally) a stick (for punishing, writing, fighting, ruling, walking, etc.) or (figuratively) a clan
to drive (an animal, a workman, a debtor, an army); by implication, to tax, harass, tyrannize
properly, to prostrate; hence, to break down, either (literally) by violence, or (figuratively) by confusion and fear
a day (as the warm hours), whether literal (from sunrise to sunset, or from one sunset to the next), or figurative (a space of time defined by an associated term), (often used adverb)
Midjan, a son of Abraham; also his country and (collectively) his descendants

5.brief: (by implication) very widely used as a relative conjunction or adverb (as below); often largely modified by other particles annexed
properly, the whole; hence, all, any or every (in the singular only, but often in a plural sense)
perhaps a military boot (as aprotection from mud
to shoe, i.e. (active participle) a soldier shod
blood (as that which when shed causes death) of man or an animal; by analogy, the juice of the grape; figuratively (especially in the plural) bloodshed (i.e. drops of blood)
to exist, i.e. be or become, come to pass (always emphatic, and not a mere copula or auxiliary)

6.brief: (by implication) very widely used as a relative conjunction or adverb (as below); often largely modified by other particles annexed
something born, i.e. a lad or offspring
to bear young; causatively, to beget; medically, to act as midwife; specifically, to show lineage
a son (as a builder of the family name), in the widest sense (of literal and figurative relationship, including grandson, subject, nation, quality or condition, etc., (like father or brother), etc.)
to give, used with greatest latitude of application (put, make, etc.)
to exist, i.e. be or become, come to pass (always emphatic, and not a mere copula or auxiliary)
above, over, upon, or against (yet always in this last relation with a downward aspect) in a great variety of applications
the neck (between the shoulders) as the place of burdens; figuratively, the spur of ahill
to call out to (i.e. properly, address by name, but used in a wide variety of applications)
an appellation, as amark or memorial of individuality; by implication honor, authority, character
to advise; reflexively, to deliberate or resolve
strength; as adjective, mighty; especially the Almighty (but used also of any deity)
father, in a literal and immediate, or figurative and remote application
a head person (of any rank or class)
safe, i.e. (figuratively) well, happy, friendly; also (abstractly) welfare, i.e. health, prosperity, peace

7.brief: properly, increasing; as noun, greatness, or (adverbially) greatly
empire
safe, i.e. (figuratively) well, happy, friendly; also (abstractly) welfare, i.e. health, prosperity, peace
a non-entity; generally used as a negative particle
an extremity; adverbially (with prepositional prefix) after
above, over, upon, or against (yet always in this last relation with a downward aspect) in a great variety of applications
properly, covered, i.e. a throne (as canopied)
David, the youngest son of Jesse
above, over, upon, or against (yet always in this last relation with a downward aspect) in a great variety of applications
dominion, i.e. (abstractly) the estate (rule) or (concretely) the country (realm)

properly, to be erect (i.e. stand perpendicular); hence (causatively) to set up, in a great variety of applications, whether literal (establish, fix, prepare, apply), or figurative (appoint, render sure, proper or prosperous)
properly, self (but generally used to point out more definitely the object of a verb or preposition, even or namely)
to suport (mostly figurative)

properly, a verdict (favorable or unfavorable) pronounced judicially, especially a sentence or formal decree (human or (participant's) divine law, individual or collective), including the act, the place, the suit, the crime, and the penalty; abstractly, justice, including a participant's right or privilege (statutory or customary), or even a style
rightness (abstractly), subjectively (rectitude), objectively (justice), morally (virtue) or figuratively (prosperity)
at this time, whether adverb, conjunction or expletive
as far (or long, or much) as, whether of space (even unto) or time (during, while, until) or degree (equally with)
properly, concealed, i.e. the vanishing point; generally, time out of mind (past or future), i.e. (practically) eternity; frequentatively, adverbial (especially with prepositional prefix) always
jealousy or envy
Jehovah, Jewish national name of God
a mass of persons (or figuratively, things), especially reg. organized forwar (an army); by implication, a campaign, literally or figuratively (specifically, hardship, worship)
to do or make, in the broadest sense and widest application
this (often used adverb)

8.brief: a word; by implication, a matter (as spoken of) or thing; adverbially, a cause
to send away, for, or out (in a great variety of applications)
the Lord (used as a proper name of God only)
to fall, in a great variety of applications (intransitive or causative, literal or figurative)
Jisrael, a symbolical name of Jacob; also (typically) of his posterity

9.brief: to know (properly, to ascertain by seeing); used in a great variety of senses, figuratively, literally, euphemistically and inferentially (including observation, care, recognition; and causatively, instruction, designation, punishment, etc.)
a people (as a congregated unit); specifically, a tribe (as those of Israel); hence (collectively) troops or attendants; figuratively, a flock
properly, the whole; hence, all, any or every (in the singular only, but often in a plural sense)
Ephrajim, a son of Joseph; also the tribe descended from him, and its territory
properly, to sit down (specifically as judge. in ambush, in quiet); by implication, to dwell, to remain; causatively, to settle, to marry
arrogance or majesty; by implication, (concretely) ornament
the heart (as the most interior organ);

10.brief: a brick (from the whiteness of the clay)
to fall, in a great variety of applications (intransitive or causative, literal or figurative)
to fell a tree; generally, to destroy anything
a cedar tree (from the tenacity of its roots)
properly, to slide by, i.e. (by implication) to hasten away, pass on, spring up, pierce or change

11.brief: to be (causatively, make) lofty, especially inaccessible; by implication, safe, strong; used literally and figuratively
Jehovah, Jewish national name of God
properly, self (but generally used to point out more definitely the object of a verb or preposition, even or namely)
narrow; (as a noun) a tight place (usually figuratively, i.e. trouble); also a pebble ; (transitive) an opponent (as crowding)
Retsin, the name of a Syrian and of an Israelite
above, over, upon, or against (yet always in this last relation with a downward aspect) in a great variety of applications
properly, self (but generally used to point out more definitely the object of a verb or preposition, even or namely)
properly, to entwine as ascreen; by implication, to fence in, cover over, (figuratively) protect

the front, of place (absolutely, the fore part, relatively the East) or time (antiquity); often used adverbially (before, anciently, eastward)
a Pelishtite or inhabitant of Pelesheth
the hinder part; hence (adverb) behind, backward; also (as facing north) the West
properly, self (but generally used to point out more definitely the object of a verb or preposition, even or namely)
Jisrael, a symbolical name of Jacob; also (typically) of his posterity

properly, iteration or continuance; used only adverbially (with or without preposition), again, repeatedly, still, more
a hand (the open one (indicating power, means, direction, etc.),
to stretch or spread out; by implication, to bend away (including moral deflection); used in a great variety of application

Jisrael, a symbolical name of Jacob; also (typically) of his posterity
the head (as most easily shaken), whether literal or figurative (in many applications, of place, time, rank, itc.)
a bulrush (as growing there); collectively a rope of bulrushes
a day (as the warm hours), whether literal (from sunrise to sunset, or from one sunset to the next), or figurative (a space of time defined by an associated term), (often used adverb)
properly, united, i.e. one; or (as an ordinal) first

the face (as the part that turns); used in a great variety of applications (literally and figuratively); also (with prepositional prefix) as a preposition (before, etc.)
